failure_modes.description: Agent incentives don't match principal goals
failure_modes.real_world_case: Fund managers churning for fees, not returns.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Agent should have 10%+ of wealth tied to principal outcomes

failure_modes.description: Agent uses superior information against principal
failure_modes.real_world_case: Real estate agents rushing sales for commission.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Agents spend 10x more time on own transactions

failure_modes.description: Agent takes risks because principal bears cost
failure_modes.real_world_case: Bank executives taking excessive risk with depositor money.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Agents should face 50%+ of downside they create

failure_modes.description: Attracting wrong type of agents
failure_modes.real_world_case: High commission structures attracting aggressive salespeople.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Incentive structure determines who you attract

failure_modes.description: Cost of oversight exceeds agency costs
failure_modes.real_world_case: Excessive compliance costs in regulated industries.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Monitoring costs should be < 10% of value at risk

failure_modes.description: Following rules becomes more important than results
failure_modes.real_world_case: Government agencies focused on compliance, not service.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If process time > value creation time, bureaucracy is winning

failure_modes.description: Growing organization for its own sake
failure_modes.real_world_case: Departments hiring to increase budget and power.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Revenue per employee should increase, not decrease

failure_modes.description: Too many approvals preventing action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Large companies unable to respond to market changes.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Decisions should take hours/days, not weeks/months

failure_modes.description: Bad news filtered out as it rises
failure_modes.real_world_case: Executives unaware of ground-level problems.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Leaders should hear unfiltered bad news weekly

failure_modes.description: Cost of coordination exceeds value of coordination
failure_modes.real_world_case: Meetings about meetings, reports about reports.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Coordination should be < 20% of time

failure_modes.description: Specialists not communicating across boundaries
failure_modes.real_world_case: Engineering and sales not talking, building wrong product.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 30% of problems are cross-functional

failure_modes.description: Too specialized to adapt
failure_modes.real_world_case: Specialists unable to pivot when field changes.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 20% of time should be learning adjacent areas

failure_modes.description: Only seeing problems through specialist lens
failure_modes.real_world_case: To a hammer, everything looks like a nail.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Every problem should be viewed through 3+ lenses

failure_modes.description: Specialists protecting knowledge for job security
failure_modes.real_world_case: Key person risk from undocumented expertise.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: No single person should be > 20% of critical knowledge

failure_modes.description: Specialists not integrating work effectively
failure_modes.real_world_case: Components that don't work together.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Integration should be planned from start, not afterthought

failure_modes.description: Getting worse as you get bigger
failure_modes.real_world_case: Large companies becoming slow and bureaucratic.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Watch for efficiency decline after 150-person teams

failure_modes.description: Getting big without sustainable advantage
failure_modes.real_world_case: Groupon - scale without defensibility.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Scale without moat = race to bottom

failure_modes.description: Scaling before product-market fit
failure_modes.real_world_case: Startups burning cash on growth before proving model.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Don't scale until LTV > 3x CAC

failure_modes.description: Ignoring small opportunities that don't scale
failure_modes.real_world_case: Large companies ignoring profitable niches.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Today's niche can be tomorrow's mainstream

failure_modes.description: Losing culture as you scale
failure_modes.real_world_case: Startups losing innovation culture as they grow.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Culture degrades 10% with each doubling of headcount

failure_modes.description: Not enough buffer for uncertainty
failure_modes.real_world_case: Companies with no cash reserves failing in downturns.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 6-12 months cash runway minimum

failure_modes.description: Gradually reducing safety margins
failure_modes.real_world_case: NASA Challenger - normalized deviance from safety standards.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Safety margins should never decrease

failure_modes.description: Precise calculations creating false confidence
failure_modes.real_world_case: Financial models with precise but wrong assumptions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Add 20-30% margin to all precise calculations

failure_modes.description: Safety margin in area that doesn't matter
failure_modes.real_world_case: Over-engineering unimportant features, under-engineering critical ones.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 80% of margin should be on 20% of critical risks

failure_modes.description: Racing to bottom removes all safety
failure_modes.real_world_case: Airlines cutting maintenance to compete on price.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Some margins are non-negotiable regardless of competition

failure_modes.description: Not listening to signals
failure_modes.real_world_case: Companies ignoring customer complaints until crisis.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Every feedback should have response within 48 hours

failure_modes.description: Feedback comes too late to be useful
failure_modes.real_world_case: Annual reviews when problems need immediate attention.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Feedback should come within 1 cycle of action

failure_modes.description: Reinforcing loops spiraling out of control
failure_modes.real_world_case: Bank runs - fear causing withdrawals causing more fear.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Positive feedback loops need external limits

failure_modes.description: Measuring and responding to wrong things
failure_modes.real_world_case: Optimizing for clicks instead of value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Any metric that becomes a target ceases to be a good metric

failure_modes.description: Getting feedback but unable to act on it
failure_modes.real_world_case: Frontline employees seeing problems but unable to fix.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Feedback receiver should have authority to act 80% of time

failure_modes.description: No backup for critical components
failure_modes.real_world_case: Key person leaving and taking all knowledge.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Every critical function needs 2+ capable people

failure_modes.description: Backups that fail together
failure_modes.real_world_case: Backup generators in same flood zone as primary.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Redundant systems should have < 10% correlation

failure_modes.description: Not investing in redundancy until too late
failure_modes.real_world_case: No disaster recovery until after disaster.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Redundancy cost should be 5-15% of critical system cost

failure_modes.description: Backups that don't work when needed
failure_modes.real_world_case: Backup systems that fail during actual emergency.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Test redundancy quarterly minimum

failure_modes.description: Too much redundancy wasting resources
failure_modes.real_world_case: Multiple backup systems for non-critical functions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Match redundancy level to criticality and risk

failure_modes.description: Following checklist mechanically without comprehension
failure_modes.real_world_case: Compliance checklists checked without actual compliance.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Users should be able to explain why for each item

failure_modes.description: Checklists not updated for current conditions
failure_modes.real_world_case: Using old procedures for new systems.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Review checklists quarterly or after any incident

failure_modes.description: Too many items reducing effectiveness
failure_modes.real_world_case: Long checklists that get skipped or rushed.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Checklists should be < 10 items for routine use

failure_modes.description: Thinking checklist completion means safety
failure_modes.real_world_case: Checklist complete but novel risk not covered.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Checklists cover known risks, judgment covers unknown

failure_modes.description: Experts refusing to use checklists
failure_modes.real_world_case: Experienced surgeons skipping safety checklists.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Checklists reduce errors 30-50% even for experts

failure_modes.description: Making things too simple, missing important complexity
failure_modes.real_world_case: Simple models missing critical variables.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simple as possible, but no simpler

failure_modes.description: Preferring complex explanations when simple ones work
failure_modes.real_world_case: Elaborate trading strategies underperforming simple index.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simple strategies beat complex 70% of time

failure_modes.description: Simplifying wrong aspect of problem
failure_modes.real_world_case: Simplifying user interface but complicating user journey.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplify what matters to user, not what's easy to simplify

failure_modes.mode: Simplicity as excuse for not understanding
failure_modes.description: Using Occam's Razor to avoid deep analysis
failure_modes.real_world_case: Simple explanation that's simply wrong.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplicity should emerge from understanding, not replace it

failure_modes.description: Simple in one context, complex in another
failure_modes.real_world_case: Solution simple for experts, complex for novices.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplicity is relative to the audience
